item.title: Researchers Find Thousands of OpenClaw Instances Exposed to the Internet | Protean Labs | Engineering Blog
item.description: Security researchers have discovered thousands of OpenClaw AI agent instances exposed to the internet, highlighting how rapid adoption can outpace secure deployment practices.

item.title: My thousand dollar iPhone can't do math
item.description:
TL;DR:
My iPhone 16 Pro Max produces garbage output when running MLX LLMs. An iPhone 15 Pro runs the same code perfectly. A MacBook Pro also runs the same code perfectly. The tensor outputs on the 16 show numerical values an order of magnitude wrong. I suspect it points

item.title: URLs are part of the product experience
item.description: A URL is like a look behind the curtain. You can hide messy code behind a beautiful interface, but it's hard to hide a messy architecture from the URL.

item.title: Recreating My Email Server with Claude
item.description: TL;DR: I recently used Claude to successfully recreate my email server's setup in NixOS with enhanced security and monitoring. You can find my setup on GitHub and deploy it yourself if you'd like.

item.title: The API Tooling Crisis: Why developers are abandoning Postman and its clones?
item.description: I’ve been a Postman user for my entire developer career. I remember when it was just a simple Chrome extension that made pentesting APIs slightly less painful. Those were simpler times. Today, I find myself joining the growing exodus of developers abandoning these tools because they sell out.

item.title: Converting floats to strings quickly
item.description: When serializing data to JSON, CSV or when logging, we convert numbers to strings. Floating-point numbers are stored in binary, but we need them as decimal strings. The first formally published algorithm is Steele and White's Dragon schemes (specifically Dragin2) in 1990. Since then, faster methods have emerged: Grisu3, Ryū, Schubfach, Grisu-Exact, and Dragonbox. In … Continue reading Converting floats to strings quickly
